title-group.article-title: Antihyperglycemic and antihyperlipidemic activities of ethanolic extract of Zygophyllum album in streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice

article-meta.aff: 1Unité de Toxicométrie and Chronobiométrie, Laboratoire de Biosurveillance de l'Environnement (LR01/ES14), Faculté des Sciences de Bizerte, Université de Carthage, Zarzouna, Tunisie
2Département des Sciences de la Vie, Faculté des Sciences de Bizerte, Université de Carthage, Zarzouna, Tunisie
3Laboratoire de Pharmacologie (04/UR/09-01), Faculté de Médecine de Monastir, Université de Monastir, Monastir, Tunisie

author-notes.corresp: Jamel El Ghoul, Unité de Toxicométrie & Chronobiométrie, Laboratoire de Biosurveillance de l'Environnement (LR01/ES14), Faculté des Sciences de Bizerte, Université de Carthage, 7021 Zarzouna, Tunisie. Email: jamel.elghoul@yahoo.fr

abstract.p: Zygophyllum album has been mentioned in Tunisian system of folk medicine to be of value in the treatment of diabetes mellitus. The present study was designed to investigate the possible antihyperglycemic effects of ethanolic extracts of the whole plant of Z. album on blood glucose, plasma insulin, serum lipids and hepatic glycogen and metabolism enzymes of carbohydrate in streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic mice. Administration of the ethanolic extract from plant (100 and 300 mg/kg body weight) for 14 days resulted in significant reduction in plasma glucose, cholesterol, triglycerides, low-density lipoprotein, very-low-density liprotein, hepatic glucokinase and glycogen in STZ diabetic mice. In addition to that, significant increase in plasma high-density lipoprotein, hepatic phosphofructokinase and glucose-6 phosphate dehydrogenase was observed in STZ diabetic mice. After administration of the ethanolic extract, the increased level of plasma insulin is not significant in diabetic mice. In conclusion, the present results showed that the ethanolic extract of Z. album possesses significant antihyperglycemic and antihyperlipidemic effects in experimental model of diabetes mellitus.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Diabetes is a serious metabolic disorder with micro- and macrovascular complications that results in significant morbidity and mortality. The estimated incidence of diabetes mellitus and projection for the year 2010, as given by International Diabetes Federation, is 239 million (Gandhi, 2001). Trends in the last 10 years are influencing the supply and demand for health care in diabetes (Bottomely and Raymond, 2007).

Traditional medicines derived mainly from plants play a major role in the management of diabetes mellitus (Karunanayake and Tennekoon, 1993; Narayana and Dobriyal, 2000; Patel and Srinivasan, 1997). Herbal remedies are apparently effective, produce minimal or no side effects in clinical experience and are of relatively low costs as compared to oral synthetic hypoglycemic agents (Gupta et al., 2005). In recent years, the role of alternative therapeutic approaches has become very popular (Yamagishi et al., 2001) and since a single plant may have many pharmacological activities (antidiabetic, antioxidant and antistress activities), they can be effectively utilized to delay or counter diabetic complications. Hence treatment with herbal drugs has an effect on protecting β-cells and smoothing out fluctuation in glucose levels (Elder, 2004; Jia et al., 2003).

Various plant extracts such as Gongronema latifolium (Ugochukwu and Babady, 2003), Ricinus communis (Shokeen et al., 2008), Zygophyllum gaetulum (Jaouhari et al., 2000) and Zygophyllum coccineum (Gibbons and Oriowo, 2001) had been evaluated as the treatment of diabetes. The leaves decoction of Zygophyllum album (Zygophyllacae) is widely used to treat hyperglycemia in folk medicine, in Tunisia; but only few studies had investigated its effects and mechanism of action. Streptozotocin (STZ) is frequently used to induce diabetes mellitus in experimental animals through its toxic effects on pancreatic β-cells (Kalendra et al., 2002; Kim et al., 2003; Stefek et al., 2002; Yamagishi et al., 2001). According to several reports in STZ-induced diabetes mellitus, hyperglycemia is accompanied by increased levels of serum cholesterol and triglyceride (TG; Choi et al., 1991; Platel et al., 1993; Prince et al., 1999; Rao et al., 1999; Sharma et al., 1997). Thus, Momordica charantia has been reported to significantly reduce the serum cholesterol levels in normal rats (Platel et al., 1993); and a related plant, Momordica cymbalaria, has also been shown to significantly reduce serum cholesterol and TGs in alloxan diabetic rats (Rao et al., 1999).

The present study is aimed at assessing the claimed antidiabetic effect of Z. album in mice. To assess the influence of the ethanolic extract of Z. album on fasting blood sugar and insulin, liver glycogen and enzymes and lipid profiles on normal and STZ-induced diabetic mice were evaluated.

sec.title: Experimental animals
sec.p: Adult Swiss albino mice of either sex (Mus musculus) weighing approximately 25 g (housed 4–5 per cage) were used in this study. Animals were housed in an air-conditioned animal room at 23 ± 2°C, with a 12-h/12-h light/dark photoperiod and relative humidity of 50-60% and maintained with ad libitum feeding and water.

sec.title: Chemicals and reagents
sec.p: Reagents were obtained from Sigma Aldrich (Milano, Italy) and Merck (Darmstadt, Germany) and were of the highest commercial grade available.

sec.title: Preparation of the ethanolic extract
sec.p: Mature whole Z. album (Zygophyllaceae) plants were collected in Tunisian South (Douz/Gbéli) between May and July 2007. The plant was identified by Mr El-Ouni botanist and professor Emeritus at the University of Carthage (Bizerte, Tunisia). A voucher specimen was deposited in the herbarium of our laboratory. The plant material was dried at ambient temperature and stored in a dry place prior to use. The plant was washed well with water, dried at room temperature in the dark and then ground in an electric grinder to give a coarse powder. The powder was extracted with absolute ethanol (100 g/1 L/48 h) using a mechanical stirrer till exhaustion. The extract was filtered with Whatman filter paper (type 4), and the filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure on rotavapor (RE 300) at 60°C temperature. The yield of this extract was 8.06%.

sec.title: Induction of experimental diabetes
sec.p: The overnight-fasted mice were made diabetic with STZ (Sigma, St Louis, Missouri) at a dose of 45 mg/kg intraperitoneally (i.p.). The STZ was freshly dissolved in citrate buffer (0.01 M, pH 4.5) and kept on ice prior to use (Siddique et al., 1987). Control mice received only the buffer. A week after the injection of STZ, diabetes was confirmed in STZ-treated mice with fasting blood glucose levels above 250 mg/dl.

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p:
The mice were randomly divided into the following five groups with eight mice per group:
Group I: normal control mice or “negative control” received only vehicle solutions.
Group II: diabetic control mice served as positive control group received single dose of STZ (45 mg/kg, i.p.).
Group III: diabetic mice received the ethanolic extract of Z. album (100 mg/kg, orally (p.o.)).
Group IV: diabetic mice received the ethanolic extract of Z. album (300 mg/kg, p.o.).
Group V: diabetic mice received gliclazide (25 mg/kg, i.p.).
Animals were treated by oral gavage once a day for a period of 14 days. At the end of the experimental period, the animals were fasted for 12 h. Blood was collected by retro-orbital puncture and mice were killed by blood loss. The liver was removed from each mouse, blotted dry and quickly weighed, and was frozen in liquid nitrogen and then stored at −80°C until analysis.

sec.title: Blood glucose
sec.p: Blood glucose was estimated by O-toluidine method of Sasaki et al. (1972). A 0.1 ml of the blood was mixed with 1.9 ml of 10% trichloroacetic acid solution to precipitate proteins and then centrifuged. A 1.0 ml of supernatant was mixed with 4.0 ml of O-toluidine reagent and was kept in boiling water bath for 15 min and then cooled. The absorbance was read at 620 nm. Data were expressed as mg/dl.

sec.title: Plasma insulin
sec.p: Plasma insulin was determined by the method of Andersen et al. (1993) using assay kit (Sigma Diagnostics, St Louis, Missouri).

sec.title: Glucokinase
sec.p: Glucokinase (GK) was estimated by the method of Newgard et al. (1983). Weighed amounts of liver tissues (0.3–0.5 g) were homogenized in 9 volumes of 50 mM Tris/HCl buffer, pH 7.4. After centrifugation at 12,000g for 20 min at 4°C, the supernatant was used to measure the enzyme activity. The assay mixture contained 100 mM KCl, 10 mM dithiothreitol (DTT) and 1 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA).

sec.title: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase
sec.p: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) was estimated by the method of Bergmeyer (1984). Weighed liver tissues were homogenized with ten times their weight in volume of 0.1M-Tris/HCl buffer, at pH 7.6, containing 1 mM EDTA. The homogenates were centrifuged at 10,000g for 15 min and the supernatants were used for the enzyme assay. Increase in absorbance of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate produced was measured at 340 nm.

sec.title: Phosphofructosamine
sec.p: Phosphofructosamine was estimated by the method of Castano et al. (1979). Weighed amounts of liver tissues (0.3–0.5 g) were homogenized with 10 times their weight (in volume) of 50 mM Tris/HCl buffer (pH 8.2) containing 5 mM MgSO4ċ7H2O, 1 mM EDTA and 10 mM DTT. The homogenates were centrifuged at 20,000g for 15 min at 4°C. The enzyme activity was measured at 37°C following the formation of NADH at 340 nm for 3 min at intervals of 30 s.

sec.title: Hepatic glycogen
sec.p: Glycogen content was determined by the method described by Ong and Khoo (2000). Weighed amounts of liver tissues (0.3–0.5 g) were homogenized in 10 volumes of ice-cold 30% KOH and boiled at 100°C for 30 min. Glycogen was precipitated with ethanol, pelleted, washed and resolubilized in distilled water. Glycogen content was determined by treatment with anthrone reagent and measured at 625 nm.

sec.title: Estimation of lipid profile
sec.p: Lipid profiles were estimated by the method of Yadav et al. (2008) using commercially available kits. Total cholesterol (TC), high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and TG levels in serum were determined according to the instructions of the manufacturer (Sigma Diagnostics). For the determination of very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) and low-density lipoprotein (LDL), Friedewald et al.’s (1972) formula was used which states: VLDL cholesterol = TG/5 and LDL cholesterol = TC − (VLDL + HDL cholesterol).

sec.title: Protein determination
sec.p: Protein content was determined by the method of Bradford (1976) using assay kit (Sigma Diagnostics).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Results are expressed as means ± standard deviation. Comparison of the means between groups was performed by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by multirange post hoc of Dunnett’s test, which was used to compare means between positive control (group II: diabetic control mice) versus all other groups. Statistical analyses were conducted using GraphPad InStat and GraphPad Prism version 3.0a for MacIntosh (GraphPad Software, San Diego, California, USA). All statistical tests were two-tailed, and a p value of 0.05 or less was considered significant.

sec.title: Effects of ethanolic extract of Z. album on blood glucose and plasma insulin
sec.p: Table 1 shows the level of blood glucose and plasma insulin in control and experimental diabetic animals. There was a significant elevation in blood glucose level (p < 0.001, one-way ANOVA) with significant decrease in plasma insulin levels (p < 0.001, one-way ANOVA) in STZ diabetic mice (group II), compared with control mice (group I). Administration of ethanolic extract of Z. album at a dose of 100 mg/kg (group III), 300 mg/kg (group IV) and the gliclazide (group V) to diabetic mice significantly decreased the level of blood glucose (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test) and increased plasma insulin gain to near normal level (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test) except for group III for this latter case.

caption.p: Effects of ethanolic extract of Zygophyllum album on blood glucose and plasma insulin levels in STZ-induced diabetic mice.a

fn.p: aBlood glucose and plasma insulin levels were measured by assay kits. Values are given as mean ± SD for 5 groups of 8 animals each. Statistical analysis by one-way ANOVA revealed an overall significant difference among groups: (i) blood glucose (F(4, 35) = 375.3; p < 0.001) and (ii) plasma insulin (F(4, 35) = 32.49; p < 0.001).
b p < 0.05 indicates significance versus diabetic control (positive group) by one-way ANOVA followed by post hoc Dunnett’s test.

sec.title: Effect of ethanolic extract of Z. album on hepatic glycogen content
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the hepatic glycogen content in the nondiabetic and STZ-induced diabetic mice after 14 days of repeated oral administration of saline and ethanolic extract from Z. album. The results obtained for the glycogen content indicate that there is significant difference between the diabetic control and diabetic mice treated with the aqueous extract (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test).

caption.p: Effect of ethanolic extract of Zygophyllum album on hepatic glycogen level in streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic mice. The data are expressed as mean ± SD (n = 8) and assays were carried out in triplicate. A one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) showed a difference between groups (F(4, 35) = 424.9; p < 0.001). *p < 0.05 indicates significance versus diabetic control (positive group) by one-way ANOVA followed by post hoc Dunnett’s test.

sec.title: Effects of ethanolic extract of Z. album on hepatic enzymes
sec.p: The activities of hepatic hexokinase, GK and phosphofructokinase (PFK) in nondiabetic and diabetic mice treated repeatedly with ethanolic extract of Z. album for 14 days are shown in Figure 2. Significantly increased activity of GK (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test) and decreased activities of the G6PD (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test) and phosphofructosamine (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test) were observed in the liver of STZ-induced diabetic mice (group II: positive control) when compared with the normal controls (group I: negative control). The ethanolic extract of Z. album was able to significantly decrease the activity of GK activity (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test) and increase the activity of PFK and G6PD (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test) in diabetic mice (groups III and IV).

caption.p: Effects of ethanolic extract of Zygophyllum album on hepatic glucokinase (a), glucose-6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) (b) and phosphofructosamine (c) levels in streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic mice. The data are expressed as mean ± SD (n = 8) and assays were carried out in triplicate. Statistical analysis by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) revealed an overall significant difference among groups: (a) glucokinase (F(4, 35) = 566.6; p < 0.001), (b) G6PD (F(4, 35) = 280; p < 0.001) and (c) phosphofructosamine (F(4, 35) = 212.5; p < 0.001). *p < 0.05 indicates significance versus diabetic control (positive group) by one-way ANOVA followed by post hoc Dunnett’s test.

sec.p: The oral administration of 25 mg/day of gliclazide to diabetic mice restored the hepatic activities of GK, PKK and G6PD to near control levels.

sec.title: Effect of ethanolic extract of Z. album on the content of serum lipid profiles
sec.p: Serum TC, TG, LDL, VLDL, and HDL levels of the experimental groups of animals are shown in Table 2. Serum TC, TG, LDL, and VLDL were significantly higher (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test) in STZ-induced diabetic mice (group II: positive control) than those in normal controls (group I: negative control). Decreased levels of HDL were observed in STZ-induced diabetic mice compared to normal untreated mice (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test). Treatment with ethanolic extract of Z. album and gliclazide resulted in a significant decrease in TC, TG, LDL and VLDL levels compared to those in STZ-induced diabetic mice (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test). Serum HDL levels were significantly increased in the treated diabetic group (p < 0.05, post hoc Dunnett’s test).

caption.p: Effects of ethanolic extract of Zygophyllum album on serum lipid profiles content in STZ-induced diabetic mice.a

fn.p: TC: plasma total cholesterol; HDL: high-density lipoprotein; VLDL: very-low-density lipoprotein; LDL: low-density lipoprotein; TG: triglyceride.

aValues are expressed as mmol/L and are given as mean ± SD for 5 groups of 8 animals. Statistical analysis by one-way ANOVA showed an overall significant difference between groups: (i) TC (F(4, 35) = 375.3; p < 0.001), (ii) HDL (F(4, 35) = 32.49; p < 0.001), (iii) VLDL (F(4, 35) = 150.7; p < 0.001), (iv) LDL (F(4, 35) = 705.72; p < 0.001), (v) TG (F(4, 35) = 154.8; p < 0.001). The lipid profiles were measured using kits.
b p < 0.05 indicates significance versus diabetic control (positive group) by one-way ANOVA followed by post hoc Dunnett’s test.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Diabetes mellitus is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by a high blood glucose concentration (hyperglycemia), which greatly increases the risk of blindness, heart disease and microvascular complications (Kim et al., 2006). Diabetes mellitus is characterized by a reduced capacity of the β-cells of the pancreas to release sufficient insulin to induce the activity of glucose metabolizing enzymes irrespective of whether the cells are destroyed as in type 1 diabetes (IDDM) or intact as in type 2 diabetes (NIDDM; Panneerselvam and Govindaswamy, 2002) and is associated with profound alterations in the plasma lipids, TGs and lipoprotein profile and with an increased risk of coronary heart disease (Fontbonne et al., 1989; Huang et al., 1988; Maghrani et al., 2004; Motta et al., 2001). High level of TC is one of the major factors for coronary heart diseases and it is well known that hyperlipidemia and the incidence of atherosclerosis is increased in diabetes (Tan et al., 2005). In our investigation, the activities of some carbohydrate metabolizing enzymes such as G6PD, GK, PFK and glycogen content were measured in the livers of nondiabetic and STZ-induced diabetic mice, and the effects of repeated 2-week oral treatment with ethanolic extract of Z. album were evaluated.

Since STZ is known to destroy pancreatic β-cells, the present findings appear to be in consonance with the earlier suggestion of Kumar et al. (2006) that sulfonylureas have extrapancreatic antihyperglycemic mechanism of action secondary to their insulin secreting effect and the attendant glucose uptake into, and utilization by, the tissues. Apart from the regulation of carbohydrate metabolism, insulin also plays an important role in the metabolism of lipids. Insulin is a potent inhibitor of lipolysis since it inhibits the activity of the hormone-sensitive lipases in adipose tissue and suppresses the release of free fatty acids (Loci et al., 1994).

After 14 days of treatment, 100 and 300 mg/kg, ethanol extract of Z. album had reduced both the fasting blood glucose levels and increased plasma insulin in STZ-induced diabetic mice. Our results show that decreased glucose in animals may be correlated with the inhibition of glycogenolysis as suggested by increased liver glycogen (Oliveira et al., 2008; Pandikumar et al., 2009). In this context, a number of other plants have been reported to have antihyperglycemic activity with a stimulatory effect on insulin release (Gupta et al., 2009; Sharma et al., 2006). Glycogen level in various tissues especially in liver and skeletal muscle indicates direct reflection of insulin activity since it causes glycogen deposition by stimulating glycogen synthase and inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen levels in tissues (muscle and liver) decrease as the influx of glucose in the liver is inhibited in the absence of insulin and recovers on insulin treatment (Vats et al., 2004). Treatment with ethanolic extract of Z. album for 14 days significantly increased the hepatic glycogen levels in STZ diabetic-treated mice, indicating the insulin secretagogue activity. Plants like Syzygium cordatum (Musabayane et al., 2005) and Syzygium alternifolium (Kasetti et al., 2010) increase the concentration of hepatic glycogen which is similar to our results.

Diabetes is associated with profound alterations in the plasma lipid, TGs and lipoprotein profile and with an increased risk of coronary heart disease (Maghrani et al., 2004). In the present study, only the high dose (300mg/kg) of ethanolic extract of Z. album significantly increased the levels of HDL. This is an important advantage in the treatment of hypercholesterolemia particularly where low HDL is the most prevalent lipoprotein abnormality (Gupta et al., 1994). In the present study, treatment with ethanolic extract of Z. album markedly decreased both serum TG and LDL levels. High levels of TC and, most importantly, LDL cholesterol are the predictors of atherosclerosis (Temme et al., 2002). However, it is interesting to find that in the present study the ethanolic extract of Z. album at a dose of 300 mg/kg body weight not only lowered the TC, TG and LDL levels by 55%, 60% and 31%, respectively, but also enhanced the cardioprotective lipid HDL level by 52% after 14 days of treatment. This would definitely reduce the incidence of coronary events, the major cause of morbidity and death in diabetic subjects (Singh et al., 2007). Several authors have reported the antihyperlipidemic activities of medicinal plants in experimental diabetic animals (Ghule et al., 2009; Kasetti et al., 2010; Singh et al., 2007), which are similar to our results.

In summary, our results clearly indicate that ethanolic extracts of Z. album has been shown to have antihyperglycemic and antihyperlipidemic properties, which act by improving the insulin secretion and altering the carbohydrate and lipid metabolism. The hypoglycemic and hypolipidemic mechanisms of Z. album extract remain unclear. Further, chemical and pharmacological investigations should be carried out to evaluate the mechanism of Z. album extract’s hypoglycemic action. More studies are warranted to evaluate whether such therapy can be administered as an auxiliary beneficial therapeutic regimen in diabetic population.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In diabetic rats, the ethanolic plant extracts at high dose (300 mg/kg) exhibited significant antihyperglycemic and antihyperlipidemic activities than those at low dose (100 mg/kg). STZ induced reduction in HDL and insulin plasma levels, which is reversed by ethanolic extract of Z. album at high dose (300 mg/kg). It would seem to be more effective than Z. album extract at low dose (100 mg/kg) after 14 days of treatment (Tables 1 and 2). The alcoholic extract of Z. album at high dose (300 mg/kg) exhibits curative effects similar to the standard group (gliclazide at 25 mg/kg). It also shows improvement in parameters like insulin plasma level and lipid profile and hence might be of value in diabetes treatment.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The authors wish to thank Dr Hosni Slimani (Laboratory of Heteroatom Organic Chemistry, Department of Chemistry of Faculty of Sciences of Bizerta, University of Carthage) for his invaluable assistance in preparing the ethanolic extracts of the vegetal matter. This work was supported by the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research in Tunisia.

fn.label: Conflict of interest
fn.p: The authors declared no conflict of interest.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
